ygData.subject: Re: Speciation and Genome Clusters in the Encoding Space
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Colin, You have some interesting ideas for refining speciation. I wonder what sort of performance impact these changes might have. I wanted to clarify your

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=130984297; y=N9-s1cmFBHzuBVBs8K9YQ7ja8OXsabyd_SaIgJFk4JrykIQ9Mywh

Hey Colin,

You have some interesting ideas for refining speciation. I wond=
er what 
sort of performance impact these changes might have.

I wanted to =
clarify your last remark about novelty search. The 
algorithm you suggest d=
oes have certain surface similarities to 
novelty search. 

The idea of avo=
iding previously explored areas of search space is not 
new, and is known a=
s tabu search. The combination of this with 
speciation may allow for more =
efficient search by avoiding previously 
explored areas of search space whi=
le promoting genotypic diversity. As 
I understand it, this is what you wer=
e suggesting. Feel free to 
correct me if I have misrepresented your idea.
=

Novelty search also uses a tabu-search like approach to bias search, 
alth=
ough it operates in behavior space (phenotype, behavior within a 
domain) a=
s opposed to search space (genotype). This in itself is not 
original, as t=
here exists previous work that used behavior-based 
speciation with NEAT.

=
The main contribution of novelty search is to demonstrate that in 
deceptiv=
e domains searching only for novel behaviors (i.e. completely 
ignoring any=
 measure of fitness) can be more effective than a method 
that uses a measu=
re of fitness to bias search. This is a surprising 
result because nearly a=
ll practical search methods rely on measuring 
progress towards a goal. Whi=
le in deceptive domains fitness may be led 
into cul-de-sacs in search spac=
e (local optima), novelty search cannot 
be deceived in the same way since =
it is not looking for anything other 
than different ways to behave.

I do =
agree that the archive in novelty search may be similar in 
philosophy to y=
our idea of a FIFO list of dead species that guide 
search away from explor=
ed areas of search space. That is, both methods 
keep a historical record o=
f previous individuals and use that record 
to encourage search to progress=
 in alternate directions.  However, I 
would say that the archive is not th=
e defining feature of novelty 
search. 

Anyways, I think your ideas for fu=
rther exploration into speciation 
are promising, and would be interested i=
n seeing their effect on hard 
problems. I am looking forward to seeing ver=
sion 2 of sharpneat.

Joel

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <col=
in.green1@...> wrote:
>
> Here are some thoughts on speciation that probabl=
y don't warrant a
> deep discussion but I post them for the record.
> 
> Cu=
rrently sharpneat takes a casual approach to speciation and I'm
> wondering=
 if there are improvements to be had. This ties in with my
> recent post ab=
out genome compatibilty metrics and 
euclidean/manhattan
> distance.
> 
> I=
n sharpneat v2 I'm trying to make the code base more abstract and
> re-usab=
le, e.g. I'm separating the NeatGenome and EvolutionAlgorithm
> classes fro=
m being dependent on each other and also using generics 
so
> that we can p=
lug in new genomes or algorithms with minimum effort.
> Thus my previous di=
scussion resulted in my creating an
> ICompatibilityMetric<TGenome> interfa=
ce which can be plugged in to 
the
> NeatEvolutionAlgorithm.
> 
> Looking a=
t speciation again I see that at the outset I simply assign
> genomes to sp=
ecies if they are within some distance and if not then 
I
> place the new g=
enome in its own species. Independent of this I also
> adjust the compatibi=
lity threshold once per generation in an attempt
> to keep the species coun=
t between some limits (which has its own
> problems and is another email in=
 the making). A possible problem 
with
> this approach is that the first at=
tempt at speciation will probably
> just assign the first N genomes in the =
population as being the first
> genome in each species - these genomes then=
 become [temporary]
> exemplars for the species, that is, the remaining gen=
omes are 
compared
> against them and if they are close enough to an exempl=
ar they are
> assigned to that species.
> 
> As an alternative approach I w=
as thinking of taking the discussion
> about compatibility (or distance) me=
trics a step further and 
actually
> explicitly representing where genomes =
are in the encoding space with
> something like an IEncodingSpace interface=
, the idea being that I 
take
> the total number of unique connection IDs i=
n the whole population as
> being the number of spacial dimensions, I then =
define the location 
of
> each genome in each dimension as being the connec=
tion weight for 
that
> ID (using 0 if a genome doesn't have a connection f=
or agiven ID). 
From
> here I can find the range/limits of locations (weigh=
ts) in each
> dimension, which effectively defines an enclosing hypercube t=
hat the
> current population is inside. I can now divide up the hypercube i=
nto
> equally sized sub-cubes in order to find clusters of genomes that 
ar=
e
> close together and use this as the basis of my initial set of 
species.=

> 
> In addition to all that I suspect it makes sense to keep the 
exempla=
r
> for each species consistent throughout the life of the species - so 
a
=
> genome (representing a point in space) we keep to one side, that may
> ha=
ve been removed from the population long ago. This keeps each
> species 'an=
chored' in space and prevents it from drifting. We then
> have the choice o=
f keeping a FIFO buffer of dead species as an
> indicator of parts of the s=
earch space that have recently been
> searched - avoiding these spaces when=
 creating new genomes. This is 
an
> idea I raised a few years ago and whic=
h I think is known as novelty
> search.
> 
> Colin.
>
